speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Before we get to questions, I’ll summarize today’s policy action by the Federal Open Market Committee and then I’ll place the Committee’s policy decision in the context of our economic outlook and our collective judgment regarding the appropriate path of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As indicated in the statement released earlier this afternoon, the Committee is maintaining the highly accommodative policies that we initiated at previous meetings.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We decided to keep the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to ¼ percent, and we continue to anticipate that economic conditions are likely to warrant exceptionally low levels of the federal funds rate at least through late 2014.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Our program to extend the average maturity of the Federal Reserve’s security holdings—announced in September—will continue as scheduled.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Each of these policy actions is intended to foster accommodative financial conditions that support the economic recovery in a context of price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In conjunction with today’s meeting, FOMC participants—the 5 Board members and the 12 Reserve Bank presidents—submitted their individual economic projections and policy assessments for the years 2012 to 2014 and over the long run.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: These projections serve as important inputs into the Committee’s deliberations.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Incoming information suggests that the economy has been expanding moderately.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Most Committee participants expect economic growth to remain moderate over coming quarters and then to pick up gradually.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Among other factors, and not withstanding some signs of improvement, the ongoing weakness of the housing sector still represents a headwind for recovery.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Strains in global financial markets, though less pronounced, generally, than last fall, continue to pose significant risks to the outlook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: April 25, 2012 Chairman Bernanke’s Press Conference Labor market conditions have improved in recent months, with the unemployment rate FINAL having fallen nearly a percentage point since August.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, at 8.2 percent, the unemployment rate remains elevated.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Looking ahead, the Committee anticipates that the unemployment rate will decline gradually over the next several years, reflecting the moderate pace of economic growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Specifically, participants’ projections for the unemployment rate in the fourth quarter of this year have a central tendency of 7.8 to 8.0 percent, declining to 6.7 to 7.4 percent in the fourth quarter of 2014.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For comparison, participants’ estimates of the longer-run normal rate of unemployment have a central tendency of 5.2 to 6.0 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Inflation has picked up somewhat, mainly reflecting higher gasoline prices.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, as has been the case for other recent swings in oil prices, the Committee expects that effect to be only temporary.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Moreover, survey measures and financial market indicators continue to show stability in longer-term inflation expectations.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Consequently, we anticipate that inflation will subsequently run at or below the Committee’s longer-run goal of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In particular, participants’ projections of inflation have a central tendency of 1.9 to 2.0 percent for 2012 and 1.7 to 2.0 percent for 2014.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The economic projections submitted by FOMC participants are conditioned on their individual assessments of the appropriate path of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As you can see from the chart labeled “Appropriate Timing of Policy Firming,” Committee participants have a range of views about when the initial increase in the federal funds rate is likely to be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Following a careful discussion of those views at today’s meeting, the FOMC maintained its collective judgment that economic conditions will likely warrant exceptionally low levels for the federal funds rate at least through late 2014.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In particular, a highly accommodative stance of monetary policy is warranted in light of the persistence of the factors restraining the pace of recovery and the ongoing risks to the economic outlook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Finally, the Committee took no new decisions regarding the Federal Reserve’s balance sheet today, but we remain prepared to adjust our securities holdings as appropriate to promote a stronger economic recovery in the context of price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I’d be glad to take your questions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, first, the Committee has certainly been bold and aggressive in terms of easing monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’ve maintained the federal funds rate close to zero since late 2008.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’ve had two rounds of so-called quantitative easing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’ve had a maturity extension program, which is ongoing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have offered guidance about the federal funds rate that goes into at least late 2014.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we have been very accommodative, and we remain prepared to do more as needed to make sure that this recovery continues and that inflation stays close to target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, in particular, we will continue to assess, you know, looking at the economic outlook, looking at the risks, whether or not unemployment is making sufficient progress towards its longer-run normal level, and whether inflation is remaining close to target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, if appropriate, and depending also on assessment of the costs and risks of additional policy actions, we remain entirely prepared to take additional balance sheet actions if necessary to achieve our objectives.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So those tools remain very much on the table, and we will not hesitate to use them should the economy require that additional support.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I would just say, first, that our projections still have inflation very close to our 2 percent target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As you point out, core inflation and some other measures of underlying inflation have been a little stronger than expected.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But I would say first that some of the movement in the first quarter, for example, seems to have come from transitory sources like nonmarket components.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And the fundamentals of inflation—in particular, inflation expectations; the amount of slack in the economy; the commodity price behavior, which has been relatively well-controlled in recent months—all of those things suggest that inflation is going to stay close to or perhaps a bit below our 2 percent target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, as I mentioned in the opening remarks and as we said in our briefing, the recent rise in gasoline prices has created a temporary bulge in headline inflation, in overall inflation, but we expect that to pass through the system and, assuming no new shocks in the oil sector, inflation ought to moderate to about 2 percent later this year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The lower bound rose—again, this represents 17 distinct views—but I would guess that the reason is that the data have come in a little bit firmer, core inflation has been a little stronger than was expected.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But those differences are not particularly large.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I’m very comfortable with the consensus view that we enunciated today, and I think that the Committee broadly is comfortable—a 9-to-1 vote in favor of this guidance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So again, that represents a very accommodative stance of policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Our intention is to maintain a highly accommodative stance of policy for the foreseeable future, and we remain able and willing to take further action if necessary.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: At the same time, I think it is worth noting that the forward guidance on the federal funds rate is conditional on the data, and if the data were to come in much stronger than expected, we would adjust the guidance appropriately.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So it’s not unconditional; it does depend on how the outlook evolves.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And again, should the outlook strengthen notably, then we would have to respond to that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I can only say qualitatively that the Committee will continue to look at the evolution of the outlook, try to assess whether unemployment is making sufficient progress towards our objectives, and, in particular, whether the recovery is still continuing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And we remain prepared to use balance sheet tools to support the recovery and to help make sure that unemployment continues its downward path towards longer-run normal levels.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, there’s certainly a range of views, as you’ve noted, but these projections are inputs into a Committee process.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And it’s in the Committee meeting that we had yesterday and today where we debate not only the possible outcomes, but also the risks, the uncertainties, all the things that inform our collective judgment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And as I said, the Committee had no difficulty coming to a consensus that the guidance that we gave is still appropriate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Again, if there’s a substantial change in the economic outlook in either direction, then the guidance would change appropriately.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But for now, I think the Committee is comfortable with the consensus statement that we put out.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, again, the individual projections are inputs to the Committee decision, so the Committee decision is the critical element in that respect.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We are continuing to work to become more transparent, and we have a variety of things that we’re looking at, so you’ll have to stay tuned for that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But again, the Committee was quite comfortable with the consensus that we have reported today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Let me tackle that second part first.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So there’s this view circulating that the views I expressed about 15 years ago on the Bank of Japan are somehow inconsistent with our current policies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That is absolutely incorrect.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Our—my views and our policies today are completely consistent with the views that I held at that time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I made two points at that time to the Bank of Japan.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The first was that I believe that a determined central bank could and should work to eliminate deflation—that is, falling prices.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The second point that I made was that when short-term interest rates hit zero, the tools of a central bank are no longer—are not exhausted, there are still other things that the central bank can do to create additional accommodation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, looking at the current situation in United States, we are not in deflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: When deflation became a significant risk in late 2010, or at least a modest risk in late 2010, we used additional balance sheet tools to help return inflation close to the 2 percent target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Likewise, we have been aggressive and creative in using non-federal-funds-rate-centered tools to achieve additional accommodation for the U.S. economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So the very critical difference between the Japanese situation 15 years ago and the U.S. situation today is that Japan was in deflation, and, clearly, when you’re in deflation and in recession, then both sides of your mandates, so to speak, are demanding additional accommodation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In this case, it’s—we are not in deflation, we have an inflation rate that’s close to our objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, first I would again reiterate that we are doing a great deal; policy is extraordinarily accommodative.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We—and I won’t go through the list again, but you know all the things that we have done to try to provide support to the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The view of the Committee is that that would be very reckless.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have—we, the Federal Reserve, have spent 30 years building up credibility for low and stable inflation, which has proved extremely valuable in that we’ve been be able to take strong accommodative actions in the last four or five years to support the economy without leading to an unanchoring of inflation expectations or a destabilization of inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: To risk that asset for what I think would be quite tentative and perhaps doubtful gains on the real side would be, I think, an unwise thing to do.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I think we’ll have to take fiscal policy into account to some extent, but I think it’s very important to say that if no action were to be taken by the fiscal authorities, the size of the fiscal cliff is such that there’s, I think, absolutely no chance that the Federal Reserve could or would have any ability whatsoever to offset that effect on the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I—as I have said many times before, it’s imperative for Congress to give us a fiscal policy that achieves two principal objectives.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The first is, of course, to achieve fiscal sustainability over the longer term; that is critical, and that’s something that needs to be addressed.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: At the same time, I think that can be done in a way that doesn’t endanger the short-term recovery of the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I am concerned that if all the tax increases and spending cuts that are associated with the current law and which would take place—absent any congressional action—were to occur on January 1st, that that would be a significant risk to the recovery.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I’m looking and hoping that Congress will take actions that will address both sides of that—both requirements of a good fiscal policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, again, these are the views of the participants, the 17 participants.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So the basic feature that is described in our statement, which is that growth seems likely to pick up over time, is still obviously in our projections.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The 2013 numbers are stronger than the 2012 numbers, and the 2014 numbers are stronger than the 2013 numbers.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And the reason for that expected pickup over time is, first, a very accommodative monetary policy, which continues to provide support for the recovery.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But in addition, some of the headwinds that have been affecting our recovery—such as the housing market, financial stresses, credit tightness, and so on—some of those things we hope will be lifting over time and will allow the economy to grow more quickly and approach more quickly its longer-run full employment level.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The reason—I don’t know precisely why there’s been a slight downgrade in years further out, but I suspect that the fiscal issues may be part of that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So it’s not a ceiling, it’s a symmetric objective, and we attempt to bring inflation close to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And in particular, if inflation were to jump for whatever reason—and we don’t have, obviously don’t have perfect control of inflation—we’ll try to return inflation to 2 percent at a pace which takes into account the situation with respect to unemployment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The risk of higher inflation—you say 2½ percent; well, 2½ percent expected change might involve a distribution of outcomes, some of which might be much higher than 2½ percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And the concern we have is that if inflation were to run well above 2 percent for a protracted period, that the credibility and the well-anchored inflation expectations, which are such a valuable asset of the Federal Reserve, might become eroded, in which case we would in fact have less rather than more flexibility to use accommodative monetary policy to achieve our employment goals.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I would cite to you, just as an example, if you look at Vice Chair Yellen’s paper, which she gave—or speech, which she gave a couple of weeks ago, where she described a number of ways of looking at the late 2014 guidance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: She showed there some so-called optimal policy rules that come from trying to get the best possible outcomes from our quantitative econometric models, and what you see, if you look at that, is that the best possible outcomes, assuming perfect certainty, assuming perfect foresight—very unrealistic assumptions—still involve inflation staying quite close to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So there is no presumption even in our econometric models that you need inflation well above target in order to make progress on unemployment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, it’s just supposed to be a factual description of what’s happening in the environment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In January, the financial markets had calmed considerably, reflecting a number of steps taken in Europe, including, notably, the two large long-term refinancing operations by the European Central Bank, which helped finance Europe’s banks for up to three years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In recent weeks, we’ve seen more market stress arising from concerns about the fiscal positions of Spain and Italy, and, you know, we’ve seen more volatility in our own markets related to that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we’re simply taking note of the fact that a portion of the improvement that we saw late last year and early this year in European financial markets and in our own financial markets has been reversed recently, nothing more intended than that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As you know, I had the opportunity over the weekend to speak with many of my European and other international colleagues because we had the G–20 and the IMF meetings here in Washington, and so we had plenty of opportunities to discuss the European situation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think it’s true that the Europeans have made substantial progress overall.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I include not only the two LTRO operations, but also the Greek debt deal, the work on the fiscal compact, and recently the setting up of a larger financial firewall that could be used to avoid contagion should another country face serious financial distress.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So progress has been made, but obviously, judging by market conditions, there’s still more work to be done, and we are counting on our European colleagues to continue to follow through their commitments and to put very strong effort into addressing what remain significant problems and concerns in Europe.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, if you compare this set of forecasts with January, you’ll see that a few members have pulled in their expected date.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But let me just reiterate that, once again, that these are just inputs into a decision process.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: They represent individual estimates, and, quite admittedly, as many of the participants said around the table, you know, these are uncertain from an individual point of view.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And as we discussed the range of considerations, including the fact that we remain uncertain about how the economy is going to evolve, I’ve talked about, for example, the so-called Okun’s law puzzle about whether or not unemployment will continue fall quickly or whether it will begin to level out.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Given those uncertainties, given the risks like the European situation or the fiscal cliff that we’ve just discussed here, that there was a quite reasonable case for maintaining the guidance at late 2014.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And as I said, there was a great deal of comfort among the participants and the Committee members with maintaining this guidance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I believe that too-big-to-fail was an important cause, or at least a propagating mechanism, of the financial crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I believe it’s absolutely incumbent upon us to do all we can to eliminate too-big-to-fail.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And what I mean by that is, a situation where a failing firm is bailed out because its collapse would have such adverse circumstance—consequences for the rest of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we are working to get rid of too-big-to-fail, and I think making some progress.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: First of all, we are very substantially increasing the supervisory and regulatory oversight of large financial institutions; that includes, for example, the Basel III rules that require higher capital for all banks but particularly for systemically important banks, more liquidity requirements, stress tests, a range of tougher supervisory requirements that are—many of them are embedded in the rule we put out on 165–166, that section of the Dodd–Frank Act.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So the first thing we’re going to do is make sure that these large institutions are stronger, that it’s much harder for them to fail, and that they are watched much more carefully and more actively by the supervisors.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The other part of eliminating too-big-to-fail, though, is that, in that circumstance where a large complex financial firm does come to the brink of failure, that it must be allowed to fail; it must be safe to fail.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And in that respect, one of the principal tools that we’ve gotten from Dodd–Frank is a so-called orderly liquidation authority, which is the FDIC’s tool, and the Federal Reserve is working closely with the FDIC there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The idea is to apply the same kind of bank resolution tools that the FDIC has used for many years on domestic banks to large complex financial firms.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, obviously, the complexity and the international aspects of these firms make that a much more challenging task, but I think we’re making progress there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have put out rules about so-called living wills, which will require large financial firms to essentially plan out how they would be disassembled.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And we’ve continued to talk with international colleagues about how we would cooperate if a multinational firm had to be put into receivership.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, indeed, part of the reason that there’s been some downgrade or potential downgrade for some U.S. financial institutions is the judgment of the ratings agencies that the so-called implicit government support that these institutions have is less than in the past.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so, I think, ultimately, what we’ll need to have is a situation where large firms are both making judgments about their size and complexity based only on the economic benefits and costs and not on too-big-to-fail considerations, and that if there is failure, that it can be done and achieved without highly adverse consequences for the financial system and the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that’s our objective, and that’s the way, I think, to end too-big-to-fail.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I think that’s part of your job to say.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think we’re making progress.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think it was an important step to make clear what our inflation objective is—I thought that was important.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And we put out a statement that described the overall policy approach of the Federal Reserve.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’ve taken a number of steps to improve communication, including these press conferences, of course.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But also, by expanding our projections and by continued, you know, work doing press—doing,sorry, doing testimonies and speeches, and most recently as you know, I did some classes—I taught some classes at a local university.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we’re doing our best both—to achieve, really, two objectives.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: One is to help make the Fed a little bit more understandable to the average person, because many people don’t understand all the arcane aspects of the Federal Reserve and of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And to be good voters and good citizens, they need to understand, you know, something about what the Fed does.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And also, to communicate with markets so that markets can better appreciate, you know, what our monetary policy plans are in order so that interest rates and other asset prices can appropriately reflect those plans.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think the evidence on the latter point is that there is a better understanding of the Fed’s policies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, you know, we’ve seen, for example, less volatility in interest rates related to greater certainty about what the Fed is likely to do.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But I want to emphasize that this is an ongoing task, it’s a work in progress, and we’re going to continue to look for ways to make ourselves better understand—more understandable and more transparent to the public.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: “Exceptionally low”; you know, one of the reasons that language in the statement is sometimes a little vaguer than you would like is because we are trying to get a consensus among 17 or at least 10 people, and different members or participants in the FOMC might have somewhat different views of what “exceptionally low” means.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Personally, I think it means something close to where we are—where we are now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, there may be circumstances where a bank or financial institution is artificially large.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And in that context, if it were posing a severe threat to financial stability, then I suppose that considering breaking it up would be something that regulators should look at.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: My own view, though, is that a more market-responsive way to address this problem is to eliminate the incentive to be too-big-to-fail.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That is, to—through tougher supervisory oversight, through higher capital requirements, through greater liquidity requirements, through restrictions on interconnectedness, et cetera, take away the benefits or force firms to internalize the costs of being large and complex.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And on the other side, as I was saying earlier, if we can safely unwind a failing firm, then we no longer have too-big-to-fail, obviously, and so I think that’s a very, very important objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The test would be that the financial markets that lend to large firms base their bond spreads and what they’re willing to pay for the stock of those firms solely on the risk-taking and on the business model of those firms and not on the fact that there’s some anticipation of a government bailout.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so I think market indicators will help us see our progress towards ending too-big-to-fail.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, to your last point, the purpose of monetary policy is to achieve our objectives of maximum employment and price stability, it’s not to disappoint or not disappoint investors.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we will take actions based on those economic objectives and not try to achieve certain market outcomes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There’s some disagreement, I think, about exactly how balance sheet actions by the Federal Reserve affect Treasury yields and other asset prices.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The view that we have generally taken at the Fed, in which I think—for which I think the evidence is pretty good, is that it’s the quantity of securities held by the Fed at a given time rather than the new purchases—the flow of new purchases—which is the primary determinant of interest rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And if that theory is correct, then at such time that our purchases come to an end, there should be relatively minimal effects on interest rates at that time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that, in fact, has been our—generally our experience in previous episodes where we have launched a program and then allowed it to come to a natural end.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Of course, we’ll continue to monitor the situation, and if we believe that financial conditions for whatever reason are inconsistent with our macroeconomic objectives, then we will act to fix that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, again, our expectation is that, at whatever point that the purchases end, that financial markets being quite forward looking will have anticipated that, and that the effects ought to be moderate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: April 25, 2012 Chairman Bernanke’s Press Conference AKIO FUJII.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I think the—I would draw two distinctions between the U.S. and Japan, or the Japanese experience.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The first is that, as I mentioned earlier—and I think this is very important—is that we acted aggressively and preemptively to avoid deflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, of course, Japan had a much bigger bubble and a much bigger shock when the bubble collapsed, and so these differences may be certainly understandable.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, again, we did avoid deflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The other thing which I think we have done reasonably well here in the United States was that we moved fairly quickly to make sure that our banks were recapitalized and were recognizing their bad assets.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I think the stress tests that we conducted last month are good evidence that the U.S. banking system is considerably stronger and, indeed, much more resilient than it was a couple of years ago.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So those two things are positives and would tend to suggest that we will avoid some of the problems that Japan has faced.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That being said, I think it’s always better to be humble and just to, you know, avoid being too confident.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And we need to continue to maintain a strong monetary policy support to make sure that the economy continues on a recovery path and returns to a more normal situation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: On declaring victory, I think it’s a little premature to declare victory.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think that keeping interest rates low is still appropriate for our economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As for the bond bubble, interest rates are low for a lot of reasons; they include monetary policy, of course, but they also include a weak economy, low inflation expectations, and safe-haven demands for U.S. Treasuries.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, of course, interest rates will rise at some point.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We hope that they do because that would be an indication that the economy is recovering and strengthening.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I think it’s important for holders of long-term securities to manage their risks and pay attention to that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But all that being said, I think, again, that there are both good reasons to continue monetary ease and good reasons for interest rates to be low.

sentence: Oh, participation, labor participation, yes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Actually, we had a very good discussion of that at the meeting because it is an important issue, trying to assess how much of the change in employment is structural, how much is cyclical, and so on.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There is, in fact, a downward trend in labor participation in the United States.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It comes from, first, the fact that we’re no longer getting increased participation from women; female participation has leveled out.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, secondly, because, as the society ages, and also for other reasons, male participation has been declining over time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So there is a downward trend that we have to take into account.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The participants at the meeting, at least some of them, suggested, though, that a good bit of the decline in participation that we’ve seen in the last few years does represent cyclical factors.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Much of it is young people, for example, who presumably are not out of the labor force indefinitely, but, given the weak job market, they are going to school or doing something else rather than working.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So one possibility and one reason why the unemployment rate may not fall as quickly going forward is that as the economy strengthens, as the labor market strengthens, many of these folks are going to come back in the labor force looking for work, which I think would be a good thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But we’ll just have to see.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But I do think—I think I would agree with the argument that a significant part of the decline over and above the downward trend in the participation rate is reflecting cyclical factors and should reverse when the economy gets stronger.

sentence: Well, the weather issue just reflects how difficult it can be to make real-time assessments of the state of the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It probably brought forward some of the hiring so that it made perhaps January and February artificially strong and March perhaps artificially a little bit weak.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It probably affected construction, manufacturing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There’s a number of things that were probably affected to some extent by the unusually warm weather that we had this winter, and we’re doing our best to try to adjust for that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re also looking at some of the seasonality issues that have arisen because of the unusually large recession in 2008 and 2009.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, again, that makes the data harder to interpret.

sentence: April 25, 2012 Chairman Bernanke’s Press Conference I advanced the hypothesis that the increase in employment we’ve seen in the last five, six FINAL months might to some extent be greater than we’d expect going forward because it represented a one-time catch-up, undoing the very sharp layoffs in 2008 and 2009.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE

sentence: If it’s correct, then job gains will be somewhat less than the 250,000 a month that we’ve been seeing recently.

sentence: So, we’ll continue to be watching the labor market.

sentence: If unemployment looks like it’s no longer making progress, that’ll be an important consideration in thinking about policy options.

sentence: We need fewer jobs monthly to keep unemployment consistent or stable than in the past—I suppose more like 100,000 a month for stability.

sentence: I don’t have an exact answer, but broadly speaking, 150–200,000 jobs or so.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But that’s a very rough estimate, and, of course, individual participants may have different views.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Again, that’s not a forecast, I’ve made a hypothesis, which would imply slower improvement in unemployment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But the possibility, of course, exists that this recovery will generate a virtuous circle with greater hiring, which in turn generates more consumer spending, and greater hiring, and so on.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That remains to be seen, and, of course, which way that goes is going to be a very important determinant of our response.
